main_definition: A saint is a person who has been recognized as holy or exceptionally good, often through canonization by a religious institution.

meanings_and_examples.definition: Religious figure venerated for their holiness
meanings_and_examples.example: Saint Peter was one of the apostles and is considered the first Pope in Christianity.

meanings_and_examples.definition: One who is seen as morally perfect or very good
meanings_and_examples.example: In many cultures, individuals who selflessly help others are revered as saints for their kindness.

meanings_and_examples.definition: A person believed to have close relationships with the divine and able to intercede on behalf of others
meanings_and_examples.example: Pope John Paul II was often invoked by Catholics, who saw him as a saintly figure capable of influencing God's will.

meanings_and_examples.definition: A person granted sainthood after being canonized by a religious institution
meanings_and_examples.example: Saint Francis of Assisi was canonized in 1228 for his devout Christian life and service to the poor.

meanings_and_examples.definition: Used colloquially to describe an admired or ideal person, often not religious in nature
meanings_and_examples.example: She's a saint when it comes to volunteering at animal shelters. She spends countless hours helping stray animals.

meanings_and_examples.definition: A term used pejoratively to describe someone with overly idealized or unrealistic views
meanings_and_examples.example: His 'saint' approach to parenting, where he expects perfection from his children at all times, can be quite harsh.
